item.title: About Affinity Peptides
item.description:
Affinity Peptides is an independent, research-focused platform dedicated to the scientific exploration of peptide biology, metabolic health, and regenerative medicine.

The purpose of this site is to curate, organize, and interpret peer-reviewed biomedical research in a way that is accessible, transparent, and evidence-based.

We focus on:

  • Peptide signaling and receptor biology
  • Metabolic regulation and obesity research
  • Growth hormone and tissue regeneration
  • Inflammatory and immune modulation
  • Emerging therapeutic peptides

All information published on this platform is derived from:

item.title: Retatrutide
item.description:
Overview

Retatrutide is an investigational triple-agonist peptide designed to target three key metabolic hormone receptors involved in weight regulation and glucose control:

  • GLP-1 (glucagon-like peptide-1)
  • GIP (glucose-dependent insulinotropic polypeptide)
  • Glucagon receptor

This multi-receptor approach is intended to improve metabolic flexibility, enhance fat loss, and preserve lean mass more effectively than single-pathway therapies.

Mechanism of Action

Retatrutide activates:

Receptor Function
GLP-1 Reduces appetite, slows gastric emptying, increases insulin secretion
GIP Enhances insulin response and nutrient partitioning
Glucagon Increases energy expenditure and fat oxidation

By stimulating all three pathways, Retatrutide produces a synergistic metabolic effect that promotes weight loss while supporting glycemic control.

item.title: Safety, Ethics, and Research Use
item.description:
Affinity Peptides exists as a scientific information platform only.

We do not:

  • Provide medical advice
  • Diagnose or treat any condition
  • Prescribe medications
  • Sell pharmaceutical products

All information presented on this website is intended strictly for educational and research purposes.

Peptides discussed on this site are:

  • Investigational compounds
  • Research chemicals
  • Studied in laboratory and clinical research settings

Any human use of peptides must be supervised by a licensed medical professional.

Readers are responsible for verifying information and consulting qualified healthcare providers before making health decisions.

item.title: Scientific Sources
item.description:
All research on Affinity Peptides is based on primary scientific literature.

Major sources include:

  • PubMed
  • National Institutes of Health (NIH)
  • New England Journal of Medicine
  • Nature
  • Cell
  • Science
  • FDA clinical trial databases

Individual research articles are cited directly on each peptide and study page.

This platform prioritizes:

  • Peer-reviewed evidence
  • Human clinical trials when available
  • Mechanistic biological research

No information is taken from blogs, forums, or non-scientific media.

We are committed to accurate sourcing and scientific integrity.
